elements.title: Hypothesis-Validated Payment Timeline: Show the Money Flow as a Visual Sequence, Not a Verbal Claim
elements.problem: Robbie was told the payment flow three times during an 8-minute call (03:25, 05:03, 06:37) and reasserted his own contradictory model three times (03:17, 04:06, 06:14), each time more forcefully ('we have to confirm the payment immediately. The contract has been fueled'). The information was delivered as verbal narrative: 'the payment for the first 30 nights would be given to you after the first night of the booking.' This is a linear, temporal explanation that requires the listener to hold the full sequence in working memory while mapping it against their existing mental model. Robbie's existing model (contract signed = payment confirmed = property held) is structurally incompatible with Split Lease's model (contract signed > guest moves in > first night > payment released). The verbal explanation failed because it presented the sequence once and expected comprehension, while the Lean UX framework demands treating every explanation as a hypothesis to be tested with market feedback. The market feedback from Robbie's call is unambiguous: three re-asks constitute hypothesis invalidation. The current information architecture has no alternative to the failed verbal sequence -- no visual representation, no progressive confirmation, no testable variant of the payment explanation.
elements.solution: Replace every verbal or text-paragraph payment explanation with a visual timeline that the host can scan in one glance. The timeline has exactly four nodes, left to right: (1) 'Agreements Signed' with a checkmark icon, (2) 'Guest Moves In' with a calendar icon, (3) 'First Night Completed' with a moon icon, (4) 'Your $1,600 Released' with a dollar icon and green highlight. Between each node, an arrow shows causation, not just sequence. The monthly amount ($1,600) appears at the endpoint because that is the host's anchor -- the number they are scanning for. This timeline is the primary information element on every screen where payment timing is relevant: the post-call landing page (onboarding), the pricing display, the proposal acceptance confirmation, and the Leases page payment schedule. Each deployment of the timeline is a separate hypothesis test: 'We believe this visual will achieve comprehension at [this phase]. We will know when [specific feedback].' The timeline is not decorative -- it is the testable MVP for payment comprehension that the verbal explanation failed to achieve.

evidence.detail: Robbie asks about payment at 03:17, is told the flow at 03:25-03:33, reasserts his model at 04:06 ('this have to be confirmed immediately'), is re-explained at 05:03-05:37, reasserts again at 06:14 ('we have to confirm the payment immediately. The contract has been fueled'). Three verbal attempts, three failures. This is the market feedback that invalidates the verbal-only hypothesis.

Gothelf: 'We believe [this statement is true]. We will know we're [right/wrong] when we see the following feedback from the market.' The hypothesis 'a verbal explanation of delayed payment release achieves host comprehension' produced clear negative feedback: three re-asks in one call. The Lean UX process requires pivoting to a new hypothesis and building a different MVP.

Gothelf: 'There is more value in creating the first version of an idea than spending half a day debating its merits in a conference room.' Build the visual timeline MVP and test it with the next five hosts rather than debating whether the verbal explanation needs better wording.

Bryant's final attempt introduces 'pre-authorized on the credit card' -- financial jargon that a non-native English speaker may not parse. Robbie's response (07:10: 'just send it to me and let me see') is not comprehension; it is deferral. The documents he receives must contain the visual timeline, not another textual explanation.

hierarchy_principle.primary: The four-node visual timeline showing the payment sequence from agreement signing to payment release. The host's expected monthly amount ($1,600) appears at the final node in the largest font on the timeline. This is the anchor the host is scanning for -- the number that confirms the system will produce their expected income.
hierarchy_principle.secondary: A single confirmation sentence below the timeline: 'You receive $1,600 after your guest's first night each month.' This restates the visual in text for hosts who process text better than diagrams, but it is never the primary element because the verbal version of this sentence already failed in the call.
hierarchy_principle.tertiary: The payment guarantee badge: 'Guaranteed by Split Lease -- even if a guest misses payment.' This references Bryant's assurance at 06:52 but appears only after the timeline and confirmation sentence, because the guarantee is meaningless until the host understands the timing.
hierarchy_principle.why: Robbie's core question is not 'will I be paid?' but 'when will I be paid?' Bryant answered the 'will' question (06:52: 'you're still getting payment') but Robbie kept returning to the 'when' question (04:06, 06:14). The information hierarchy must answer 'when' first (timeline), then 'how much' (dollar amount), then 'what if something goes wrong' (guarantee). This matches the host's question priority, not the platform's marketing priority.

disclosure_pattern.immediate: The four-node timeline and the dollar amount. Visible on page load with no interaction. The host must be able to answer 'when do I get paid?' by scanning the screen in under 5 seconds.
disclosure_pattern.on_interaction: The confirmation sentence and guarantee badge. These appear directly below the timeline and are visible on load but visually secondary. The host processes them only if the timeline triggers a 'let me read more' response.
disclosure_pattern.on_demand: Detailed payment schedule (specific dates for a specific lease), fee breakdown, and guarantee terms. Behind an expand/collapse element labeled 'See payment details.' Most hosts will not expand this on the first visit.
disclosure_pattern.timing: The timeline must be the first element the eye hits on any payment-related screen. Processing time target: under 5 seconds for the host to identify all four nodes and the dollar amount. If the host needs more than 5 seconds, the visual is too complex and the hypothesis must be iterated.

cognitive_load_constraint.rationale: Four nodes match the four sequential events in the payment flow. Three words per node ensures each can be processed in a single fixation. The dollar amount is largest because it is the host's anchor ($1,600). No financial jargon because 'pre-authorized' (Bryant at 06:37) did not achieve comprehension for a non-native English speaker.

scan_order: Dollar amount at the timeline endpoint: '$1,600' (System 1 anchor verification: 'that is my number', under 1 second)
Timeline direction: left-to-right sequence of four nodes (System 1 causation: 'this leads to that leads to my money', 1-3 seconds)
Node labels: 'Signed > Move In > First Night > Payment' (System 2 comprehension: 'the sequence makes sense', 3-5 seconds)
Confirmation sentence and guarantee badge (System 2 reinforcement, 5-8 seconds)
exclude: Paragraph-form explanations of the payment flow. The verbal version already failed. Do not repeat the same information architecture in text.
Financial terminology: 'pre-authorized,' 'disbursement,' 'remittance.' Use 'released,' 'paid,' 'guaranteed.'
Timelines with more than 4 nodes. Adding steps (e.g., 'credit check,' 'agreement review') dilutes the core message and makes the visual harder to scan.
Timelines without the specific dollar amount. An abstract timeline ('payment released') does not answer Robbie's question. He needs to see '$1,600 released.'
Payment information buried below the fold or behind navigation. If the host has to scroll or click to find when they get paid, the information architecture has failed.

elements.title: Agent-Attributed Personalized Landing Page: Continue the Conversation, Not Start a New One
elements.problem: Robbie's entire relationship with Split Lease is Bryant. He was discovered by Bryant (00:18), explained the model by Bryant, and promised documents by Bryant. His trust is 100% personal, 0% institutional. When he receives a follow-up email, his expectation is personal: 'They send it to me about email. Let me take a look on it' (07:10). The Lean UX principle of shared understanding requires that team and customer share a common mental model. But Robbie's shared understanding is with Bryant (a person), not with the platform (a product). The Lean UX MVP concept asks: what is the smallest thing we can build to bridge this gap? The current approach -- sending agreement documents from a system email -- is an untested hypothesis. If the email arrives from 'noreply@splitlease.com' with generic onboarding language, Robbie encounters an entity he has never heard of asking him to do things that do not reference the conversation he had with Bryant. This is the highest-risk information architecture failure in the host journey because it occurs at the single moment when human trust must transfer to digital trust.
elements.solution: The first digital touchpoint is a personalized landing page that functions as a direct continuation of the phone call. The information architecture of this page follows the exact structure of the call: (1) Header: 'Hi Robbie, this is Bryant following up on our call' -- agent name, agent photo, personal tone. (2) Property confirmation: 'Your renovated large studio in East Village, $1,600/month' -- the details Robbie already confirmed. (3) Guest introduction: 'Ariel and Amber are ready to move forward' -- the names Robbie already heard. (4) Payment timeline (communicates-0902-001) embedded directly. (5) Document links: 'Here are the two agreements I mentioned -- the rental agreement and the supplemental agreement' with one-sentence plain-language descriptions. (6) Action: 'Take a look and let me know if you have questions -- Bryant.' The page is sent via email from Bryant's address, not a system address. The hypothesis: 'A personalized post-call landing page will achieve higher onboarding conversion than a generic follow-up. We will know when click-to-first-action rate exceeds 40%.'

evidence.detail: Robbie: 'just send it to me and let me see, I'll send you my PMO. They send it to me about email. Let me take a look on it.' His expectation is personal: Bryant will send something to his email. His decision to proceed is gated on reviewing documents independently. The follow-up email is the single most important touchpoint between the call and platform engagement.

Gothelf: 'Shared understanding is the collective knowledge of the team that builds up over time as the team works together. It's a rich understanding of the space, the product, and the customers.' The call built shared understanding between Bryant and Robbie. The landing page must transfer that understanding to the digital interface by echoing the same details, the same names, and the same sequence that the call established.

Bryant: 'I work for a company called split lease... I got in touch with both Ariel and Amber. They came to us individually and then I basically matched them as roommates.' The company name is mentioned once; the personal narrative occupies the rest of the call. The landing page must maintain this ratio: agent and specifics are primary, brand is secondary.

Gothelf describes the MVP as the smallest thing you can build to test a hypothesis. The personalized landing page is the MVP for the agent-to-platform trust bridge. It tests whether recognition (seeing Bryant's name, the property details, and guest names) is sufficient to carry the host from human interaction to digital engagement.

hierarchy_principle.primary: Agent identity and personal greeting. Bryant's name, photo, and a conversational opening sentence. This is the trust signal that activates recognition: 'I know this person, this is the follow-up he promised.' Without this, the landing page is from an unknown entity.
hierarchy_principle.secondary: Property and guest confirmation. The specific details discussed on the call: East Village studio, $1,600/month, Ariel and Amber. These confirm that the digital touchpoint is connected to the real conversation, not a generic system message.
hierarchy_principle.tertiary: Documents and actions. The agreements, the payment timeline, and the next step. These are the new information the host needs, but they are only processable after the trust signal (primary) and context confirmation (secondary) have established that this page is 'from Bryant about my apartment.'
hierarchy_principle.why: Robbie must identify the landing page as a continuation of his call in under 5 seconds or he will treat it as spam/generic outreach. Recognition (agent name + property details) must precede any new demands. The Lean UX principle of getting out of the deliverables business applies: the landing page is not a document to be produced but an experience to be tested for its effect on conversion.

disclosure_pattern.immediate: Agent greeting, property details, and guest names. All visible in the first viewport without scrolling. The host confirms 'this is about my apartment' before encountering any new content.
disclosure_pattern.on_interaction: Payment timeline and document links appear on scroll. The host has established context (primary) and now encounters the substantive content that the call promised.
disclosure_pattern.on_demand: Full agreement PDFs, detailed payment schedule, and FAQ. These are downloadable or expandable for hosts who want depth, but never compete with the greeting and confirmation for visual priority.
disclosure_pattern.timing: The agent greeting and property details must load in under 3 seconds. The host should identify 'this is from Bryant about my apartment' within 5 seconds of page load. The full page content should be scannable in under 30 seconds.

cognitive_load_constraint.rationale: Four items in the first viewport: agent greeting, property address, rent amount, guest names. These are the four anchor points from the call that establish context. Agent photo is required because Robbie built trust with a person, not a voice -- the photo extends recognition to the visual channel. No platform jargon before personal context because 'onboarding' or 'supplemental agreement' means nothing until Robbie has confirmed this is the follow-up from Bryant. No login before recognition because requiring credentials before showing personalized content breaks the trust transfer.

scan_order: Agent name and photo: 'Bryant' (recognition trigger: 'this is the person I spoke to', under 1 second)
Personal greeting with host name: 'Hi Robbie' (recognition confirmation: 'this is addressed to me', 1-2 seconds)
Property details: 'East Village studio, $1,600/month' (context confirmation: 'this is about my apartment', 2-4 seconds)
Guest names: 'Ariel and Amber' (narrative continuation: 'these are the people we discussed', 4-6 seconds)
Payment timeline and document links (new content, now trusted, 6-15 seconds)
exclude: System-generated emails from 'noreply@splitlease.com' or any non-agent sender. The email must come from Bryant's address or display Bryant's name prominently.
Login or registration screens before showing personalized content. Recognition must precede registration.
Generic welcome messages ('Welcome to Split Lease!') that carry no call-specific information. Every word on the landing page must connect to the specific conversation.
Marketing language or value propositions ('Join thousands of hosts who trust Split Lease'). Robbie is not evaluating the brand; he is verifying that Bryant's follow-up arrived.
Platform navigation menus or dashboards on the landing page. The landing page is a single-purpose trust bridge, not a portal to the full platform.

elements.title: Plain-Language Summary Layer: Answer the Host's Three Questions Before Presenting Legal Documents
elements.problem: Robbie ends the call not knowing how many agreements exist or what they contain: 'they didn't know what, uh, how many, something of the agreement you're talking about' (07:10). After a 7-minute verbal explanation, he cannot describe the documents he will receive. The Lean UX principle of shared understanding demands that team and customer share common knowledge, but this shared understanding was not achieved. The onboarding documents are the second attempt to build it. If the documents are standard legal agreements -- dense text, formal language, multi-page -- they will fail for the same reason the call failed: they assume comprehension that does not exist. Robbie is a non-native English speaker who will read these documents alone, without Bryant available to clarify. Each unfamiliar term ('supplemental agreement,' 'pre-authorized charges') is a comprehension barrier that may not be overcome without help. The Lean UX framework treats the documents as an MVP: 'We believe that sending standard agreement documents will enable hosts to understand and accept the Split Lease model. We will know we're right when hosts sign without requesting additional explanation.' For hosts like Robbie, this hypothesis is high-risk.
elements.solution: Precede every legal document with a one-page plain-language summary that answers the three questions Robbie asked during the call. The summary uses a question-and-answer format, not legal prose. Question 1: 'When do I get paid?' Answer: 'After your guest's first night each month. Your first payment of $1,600 arrives one day after Ariel and Amber move in.' Question 2: 'Who pays?' Answer: 'Ariel and Amber pay Split Lease. Split Lease pays you. You never collect rent directly.' Question 3: 'What if they miss a payment?' Answer: 'You still get paid. Split Lease guarantees your rent even if a guest misses their payment.' Below the three answers, the summary identifies the two documents: 'You will sign two agreements: (1) The Rental Agreement -- the contract between you and your guests about living in the apartment. (2) The Supplemental Agreement -- the contract between you and Split Lease that guarantees your payment.' Each document name is followed by one sentence in plain language, not a legal description. The summary is the comprehension MVP; the full agreements are the compliance artifacts. Test: call hosts 48 hours after sending the summary and ask 'When does your first payment arrive?' If fewer than 70% answer correctly, iterate the summary.

evidence.detail: Robbie: 'Oh, they didn't know what, uh, how many, something of the agreement you're talking about. Um, just send it to me and let me see.' After a full call, Robbie cannot name the documents. The summary must build this knowledge from scratch.

evidence.source: leanux-hypothesis-driven-design.txt, Ch 2 Getting Out of the Deliverables Business
evidence.detail: Gothelf: 'Documents don't solve customer problems -- good products do.' The agreement documents are deliverables. The plain-language summary is a product -- it is designed to achieve a specific outcome (host comprehension) and can be measured against that outcome.

Robbie: 'I understand your explanation, but it goes this way. We have to confirm the payment immediately.' He claims to understand while demonstrating the opposite. The summary must detect and correct this 'false comprehension' by stating the correct flow so clearly that the host cannot hold their incorrect model alongside it.

Gothelf: 'Continuous discovery is the ongoing process of engaging the customer during the design and development process.' Follow up with hosts after they receive the summary. Did they read it? Can they answer the three questions? This feedback loop validates or invalidates the comprehension MVP.

hierarchy_principle.primary: The three Q&A pairs. Each question is stated in the host's own words (from the call). Each answer is one or two sentences in plain language with the specific dollar amount and guest names. Questions are primary because they match the host's existing concerns -- they are what Robbie was already asking about.
hierarchy_principle.secondary: The document identification. Two entries, each with a document name and a one-sentence plain-language description. This teaches the host what they will encounter next (two documents, each with a specific purpose) without requiring them to open the documents to understand their purpose.
hierarchy_principle.tertiary: Links to the full agreements. Downloadable PDFs with clear labels. These are available for the host who wants to review the legal detail, but the summary should contain everything needed to make an informed decision.
hierarchy_principle.why: Robbie's three questions (when, who, what-if) are the structure of his comprehension gap. Answering them in order, with his specific details ($1,600, Ariel and Amber), builds the shared understanding that the call failed to create. The Q&A format is cognitively cheaper than paragraph prose because it pre-segments the information into the categories the host already cares about.

disclosure_pattern.immediate: All three Q&A pairs and the document identification. The entire summary fits on one page or one screen. No scrolling required for the essential content.
disclosure_pattern.on_interaction: Document download links and the payment timeline (communicates-0902-001) embedded below the summary for visual reinforcement.
disclosure_pattern.on_demand: Full agreement text, detailed payment schedules, and legal terms. These are behind the document links and serve the host who wants to verify the summary's claims against the legal language.
disclosure_pattern.timing: The summary must be readable in under 2 minutes. Each Q&A pair should be comprehensible in under 20 seconds. If the summary requires more than 2 minutes, it violates the Lean UX small-batch-size principle.

cognitive_load_constraint.rationale: Three questions match the three concerns Robbie raised during the call. Twenty-five words per answer ensures each can be read in one breath, matching conversational comprehension. Two documents because that is how many exist. No legal jargon because 'supplemental agreement' and 'pre-authorized charges' did not achieve comprehension in the call -- use 'the contract that guarantees your payment' and 'payment is collected before the guest moves in.'

scan_order: Question 1: 'When do I get paid?' (recognition: 'this is what I was asking about', under 2 seconds)
Answer 1: specific dollar amount and timing (comprehension: 'I now know when', 2-5 seconds)
Question 2: 'Who pays?' and Answer 2 (comprehension: 'I now know the flow', 5-10 seconds)
Question 3: 'What if they miss payment?' and Answer 3 (reassurance: 'I am protected', 10-15 seconds)
Document identification: two agreements named and described (orientation: 'I know what I will sign', 15-20 seconds)
exclude: Legal language in the summary. 'Supplemental agreement' becomes 'the contract that guarantees your payment.' 'Pre-authorized charges' becomes 'payment collected before move-in.'
More than three questions. Three maps to Robbie's three concerns. Adding more dilutes the focus and increases reading time.
Answers longer than two sentences. If the answer needs more than two sentences, it is an explanation, not a summary. Explanations belong in the full documents.
The summary as an attachment. It must be embedded in the email or landing page body, not as a separate file the host may not open.
Questions framed in platform language ('How does the payment release work?'). Frame questions in the host's language ('When do I get paid?').

elements.title: Import-and-Verify Listing Path: Accept Existing Work Instead of Demanding Re-Creation
elements.problem: Robbie has already created a listing on Craigslist with photos, a description, and a price. The listing has been removed, but the work was done. He repeatedly offers to share his existing materials: 'I will send you, uh, probably so I can forward you that link. I lost where the pictures' (01:42) and 'I was sending the address on everything on the link. I'm going to send you the link of the app' (02:49). He says this twice in two minutes, revealing a strong preference for reusing existing content. The Lean UX principle of removing waste states that anything not contributing to improved outcomes is waste. Asking Robbie to recreate from scratch what he already built is pure waste -- it provides zero value to the host and depletes cognitive resources that should be preserved for the harder decisions (pricing, agreement review). The platform's 6-step listing wizard assumes hosts arrive with nothing. Robbie arrives with photos, a price ($1,600), and an address. The untested hypothesis is: 'All hosts will willingly complete a 6-step wizard from scratch.' Robbie's behavior invalidates this for hosts migrating from other platforms.
elements.solution: Design an alternative listing path for hosts who have existing content. The information architecture prioritizes verification over creation. (1) Accept input: a URL, uploaded photos, or a text description pasted from another listing. This is the entry point -- not a blank form. (2) Auto-populate: extract whatever data is available from the input and fill the listing fields. If only photos and a price exist (as in Robbie's case), create a draft with photos, the address from the call, and the rent amount. (3) Present draft for verification: 'We put together a draft listing from what you shared. Please review and correct anything that needs updating.' Verification is cognitively cheaper than creation -- the host reads and confirms rather than generating from memory. (4) Translate pricing automatically: 'You said $1,600/month. Based on [lease style], guests would pay approximately $[X] per night.' The host sees both formats without performing any calculation. (5) Test the hypothesis: 'Import-path hosts will complete listing creation 40% faster than wizard-path hosts. We will know when we measure median completion time for each path.'

evidence.detail: Robbie: 'I will send you, uh, probably so I can forward you that link. I lost where the pictures.' His instinct is to share existing work, not describe from scratch.

Gothelf: 'One of the core tenets in Lean manufacturing is the removal of anything that doesn't lead to the ultimate goal... anything that doesn't contribute to [improved outcomes] is considered waste and should be removed from the team's process.' Forcing re-creation of existing content is waste.
Robbie: 'I was sending the address on everything on the link. I'm going to send you the link of the app.' He redirects to his existing listing twice in two minutes, showing strong reuse preference.

Gothelf: 'creating only the design that is necessary to move the team forward and avoiding a big inventory of untested and unimplemented design ideas.' The import path is a small batch: accept input, auto-populate, verify. Smaller and faster to test than a redesigned wizard.

hierarchy_principle.primary: The import input zone: a prominent area where the host can paste a URL, upload photos, or drag and drop content from their existing listing. This is primary because it matches the host's first instinct (share what I already have) rather than the platform's default assumption (start from scratch).
hierarchy_principle.secondary: The auto-generated draft: a preview of the listing as it would appear on Split Lease, built from the imported content plus call data (property address, rent amount). This shows the host what the platform created from their input before asking for corrections.
hierarchy_principle.tertiary: Correction and completion fields: editable fields for anything the import did not capture or got wrong. These are inline edits on the draft, not a separate form. The host modifies a near-complete listing instead of building one from nothing.
hierarchy_principle.why: Verification (reading and correcting a draft) is cognitively cheaper than generation (filling blank fields from memory). Robbie's photos, address, and rent amount are sufficient to create a 70% complete listing. Asking him to provide the remaining 30% through inline edits respects his existing work and preserves cognitive resources for the harder decisions ahead.

disclosure_pattern.immediate: The import input zone and a message: 'Already have a listing? Paste a link or upload your photos to get started faster.' This is the first thing the host sees on the listing creation page.
disclosure_pattern.on_interaction: After import, the auto-generated draft appears with all extracted data highlighted and editable. The host sees their photos, their address, and their rent populated before encountering any blank fields.
disclosure_pattern.on_demand: The full 6-step wizard is available as a fallback for hosts who prefer to start from scratch or who have no existing content. A link ('Or create from scratch') is visible but secondary to the import path.
disclosure_pattern.timing: Import processing should complete in under 10 seconds. Draft presentation should be immediate after processing. Total time from import to published draft: under 3 minutes for a host with photos and basic details.

cognitive_load_constraint.rationale: Three blank fields maximum means the draft is at least 70% complete from the import. Five corrections maximum means the host's task is bounded and predictable. Auto price translation is required because the monthly-to-nightly conversion must never be the host's responsibility (see communicates-0902-005). No wizard steps for populated fields because forcing the host to click through steps for data already extracted wastes their time and violates the Lean UX waste removal principle.

scan_order: Import input zone: 'Already have a listing? Upload photos or paste a link' (recognition: 'yes, I have that', under 3 seconds)
Auto-generated draft with host's photos and data (verification: 'this looks right', 3-10 seconds)
Highlighted editable fields for corrections (action: 'let me fix this', 10-30 seconds)
Price translation display: '$1,600/month = $X/night' (comprehension: 'the math is done for me', 30-45 seconds)
Publish/submit action (completion, under 60 seconds total)
exclude: A mandatory 6-step wizard as the only listing path. The wizard must be available but not required when import data exists.
Rejection of incomplete imports. If only photos exist, create a photo-only draft and ask for the rest. Never restart from scratch because one field is missing.
Asking the host to re-enter information already available from the call (address, rent amount, guest names). The agent collected this data; the platform must use it.
Import paths that require technical knowledge (API keys, CSV uploads, developer tools). The input must be as simple as pasting a URL or uploading a photo.
Processing delays longer than 10 seconds without a progress indicator. The host must see immediate evidence that their import is being processed.

elements.title: Dual-Format Price Display: Always Show Monthly Income Alongside Nightly Rate
elements.problem: Robbie's pricing mental model is fixed: '$1,600 a month' (02:22). He states it as a fact. The Split Lease platform operates on per-night pricing for nights-of-the-week lease styles. Translating $1,600/month to a nightly rate is non-trivial math ($1,600 / 30 nights = ~$53/night, but actual calculation depends on lease style and nights per week). Bryant reinforced the monthly anchor: '$1,600 would be released to you after that first night' (05:03-05:37). Any pricing display that shows only a nightly rate without connecting it to $1,600/month will create a perceived discrepancy. The Lean UX framework distinguishes between output ('host sets a nightly rate') and outcome ('host is confident they will receive $1,600/month'). The pricing interface must achieve the outcome, not just produce the output. If Robbie sees '$53/night' without understanding that it equals '$1,600/month,' he will either reject the pricing as wrong or accept it without understanding, leading to a support call when the first payment does not match his expectation.
elements.solution: Accept monthly rent as the primary input and calculate the nightly rate automatically. The information architecture always shows both formats, with the monthly figure as the primary display and the nightly rate as the derived secondary. (1) Input: 'What is your monthly rent? $1,600' -- one field, the host's native format. (2) Calculation: the platform computes the nightly rate based on the lease style and displays it: '$1,600/month = approximately $53/night.' (3) Fee disclosure: if Split Lease takes a fee, show net income immediately: 'After Split Lease's service fee, you receive $[X]/month.' Never let the host discover fees through arithmetic. (4) Proposal display: 'This 3-month lease with Ariel and Amber will earn you $4,800 total ($1,600/month x 3 months).' (5) Active lease display: 'Next payment: $1,600 -- scheduled for [date].' The monthly figure is always the largest number on any financial screen. (6) Test: 'Dual-format pricing will reduce pricing support tickets by 50%. We will know when we compare ticket rates before and after deployment.'

evidence.detail: Robbie: 'it sounded like it's 16, 1600 a month would be the monthly rent.' This is his anchor. Every price display must validate against this number.

Gothelf: 'When you're creating hypotheses to test, you want to try to be very specific regarding the outcomes you are trying to achieve.' The pricing outcome is 'host sees that the rate produces their expected monthly income,' not 'host enters a nightly rate.'

Bryant: '$1,600 would be released to you after that first night.' The monthly figure is reinforced as the amount Robbie receives. The platform must never show a number that contradicts this without explicit explanation.

Gothelf: 'none of your metrics will be meaningful if you don't have a benchmark in place prior to writing your hypotheses.' Benchmark the current support ticket rate for pricing questions before deploying dual-format pricing, then measure the change.

hierarchy_principle.primary: Monthly income: the single number that matches the host's mental model. '$1,600/month' appears as the largest, most prominent number on any pricing screen. This is the anchor that tells the host 'the platform understands what I expect.'
hierarchy_principle.secondary: Nightly rate derivation: a single line showing the calculation. '$1,600/month = ~$53/night based on your lease style.' This is smaller than the monthly figure and appears directly below it. The host can verify the math but is not required to perform it.
hierarchy_principle.tertiary: Fee disclosure and net income: if applicable, 'After service fee: $[X]/month.' This appears only if there is a fee, and it is explicit, not hidden. The host should never discover a fee by doing arithmetic.
hierarchy_principle.why: Robbie stated '$1,600 a month' as his price. If the platform's primary display is '$53/night,' he must mentally calculate whether that adds up to $1,600. This mental arithmetic is exactly the kind of System 2 task that depleted users fail at (per Lean UX's focus on outcomes over outputs). Showing the monthly figure first eliminates the calculation requirement.

disclosure_pattern.immediate: Monthly income figure and the nightly rate derivation line. Both visible on load, no interaction required. The host can verify '$1,600/month' in under 2 seconds.
disclosure_pattern.on_interaction: Fee structure and net income details. These appear on tap/expand if fees are applicable.
disclosure_pattern.on_demand: Full pricing breakdown: how the nightly rate was calculated, lease style impact, comparison across different lease lengths. Behind an expand element for hosts who want to understand the math.
disclosure_pattern.timing: The monthly figure must be processable in under 2 seconds. The derivation line in under 5 seconds. If the host needs more than 5 seconds to verify their expected income, the display has failed.

cognitive_load_constraint.rationale: Two numbers: monthly income and nightly rate. The monthly figure is always visually larger because it is the host's anchor. No host arithmetic required: the platform performs all conversions. Fee disclosure is inline (not in a footnote or separate page) because discovering a fee later triggers the same distrust as discovering a different payment amount.

scan_order: Monthly income: '$1,600/month' (anchor verification: 'that is my number', under 1 second)
Nightly rate derivation: '= ~$53/night' (comprehension: 'that is how they calculate it', 1-3 seconds)
Fee and net income if applicable (transparency: 'I know what I actually receive', 3-5 seconds)
Lease total for proposals: '$4,800 over 3 months' (projection: 'I know my total earnings', 5-7 seconds)
exclude: Nightly rate as the primary or sole price display. The host thinks in months. Nightly is always derived, never primary.
Platform fees revealed only at payment time or in fine print. Fees must be disclosed where pricing is displayed.
Pricing calculators or sliders that require experimentation. Present the answer, not the tool.
Per-night pricing input as the primary field. Accept monthly rent and derive nightly. The host should never need to calculate a nightly rate.
Pricing displays that show a number different from the host's anchor ($1,600) without explicit, immediate explanation of the difference.

elements.title: Proactive Payment Assurance Loop: Notify Before the Host Needs to Check
elements.problem: Robbie's repeated demand for immediate payment confirmation (03:17, 04:06, 06:14) articulates his core desired outcome: certainty that he will be paid. This is not a feature request; it is an emotional state he requires. The Lean UX principle 'Progress = Outcomes, Not Output' distinguishes between the feature (payment processing) and the goal (host confidence). The platform currently processes payments -- that is the output. But it does not proactively assure the host that payments are coming, arriving, and continuing -- that is the outcome Robbie needs. Bryant's verbal guarantee (06:52: 'even in the case that Ariel or Amber would miss a payment, you're still getting payment') was stated once during the call. During a 6-month lease, the host needs to feel this guarantee every month, not remember it from one phone call. If Robbie has to check the Leases page to learn his payment status, the information architecture has failed. Checking is anxiety; notification is assurance. The platform must move from reactive (host checks) to proactive (platform notifies) to achieve the confidence outcome.
elements.solution: Design a three-part proactive payment assurance loop that operates on a monthly cycle. (1) Pre-notification (48 hours before payment): 'Your $1,600 payment for [month] is scheduled for release on [date].' This sets the expectation before the event. (2) Day-of confirmation (within 1 hour of processing): 'Your $1,600 payment has been released. You should see it in your account within [X] business days.' This confirms the event. (3) Next-payment preview (immediately after confirmation): 'Your next payment of $1,600 is scheduled for [next date].' This closes the loop and opens the next cycle. Each notification includes the guarantee badge: 'Guaranteed by Split Lease.' The three-part loop means the host is never in a state of 'wondering if payment is coming' for more than 48 hours. At proposal acceptance, show the full payment calendar for the lease: 'Payment 1: $1,600 on [date]. Payment 2: $1,600 on [date]...' This transforms acceptance from 'agreeing to hold the property' into 'seeing when every payment arrives.' At retention, show lifetime earnings: 'Over [X] months, you earned $[total] -- guaranteed by Split Lease.' Measure the outcome: track how often hosts check the Leases page for payment status, how often they contact support about payments. These are the signals that confidence is or is not being achieved.

evidence.detail: Robbie: 'this have to be confirmed immediately. You feel the contract phone to hold any property for you out loss.' His core fear: holding a property without confirmed payment means financial risk. Proactive notification addresses this by confirming payment before the host needs to ask.

evidence.source: leanux-hypothesis-driven-design.txt, Ch 2 Progress = Outcomes, Not Output
evidence.detail: Gothelf: 'Features and services are outputs. The business goals they are meant to achieve are outcomes. Lean UX measures progress in terms of explicitly defined business outcomes.' Payment processing is the output. Host confidence in payment security is the outcome.
Bryant: 'Even in the case that Ariel or Amber would miss a payment, you're still getting payment for the booking.' This guarantee must be reinforced every payment cycle, not stated once.

Gothelf: 'Continuous discovery is the ongoing process of engaging the customer during the design and development process.' Monitoring host payment-checking frequency and support contacts about payments is continuous discovery for whether the confidence outcome is being achieved.

hierarchy_principle.primary: The dollar amount and the date. Every payment notification leads with these two pieces of information: how much and when. '$1,600 released on March 2' is the complete primary message. The host can process this in under 3 seconds and have their core question answered.
hierarchy_principle.secondary: The guarantee badge: 'Guaranteed by Split Lease.' This appears on every payment notification as a persistent reminder that the guarantee is active, not just a one-time promise from the call.
hierarchy_principle.tertiary: The next-payment preview: 'Next payment: $1,600 on [date].' This forward-looking element closes the current payment cycle and prevents the host from entering a 'when is the next one?' anxiety state.
hierarchy_principle.why: Robbie's demand at 04:06 and 06:14 is fundamentally about certainty -- knowing that a specific amount will arrive at a specific time. The information hierarchy (amount + date first) directly answers this need. The guarantee reinforcement (secondary) maintains the assurance that Bryant's verbal promise provided. The next-payment preview (tertiary) prevents the anxiety cycle from restarting.

disclosure_pattern.immediate: Dollar amount, date, and guarantee badge. The notification contains the complete assurance message without requiring the host to tap, expand, or navigate.
disclosure_pattern.on_interaction: Payment details: transaction ID, processing status, expected bank arrival time. Available when the host taps the notification or visits the Leases page.
disclosure_pattern.on_demand: Full payment history, lifetime earnings, and lease payment calendar. Available on the Leases page for hosts who want to review their complete financial record.
disclosure_pattern.timing: Pre-notification: 48 hours before payment release. Confirmation: within 1 hour of processing. Next-payment preview: immediately after confirmation. The host should never be in a state of 'wondering about payment' for more than 48 hours.

cognitive_load_constraint.rationale: Three items per notification: amount, date, and guarantee. Five seconds to read means the notification works as a push notification or email subject line. No host action required: the notification is purely assurance, not a call to action. Guarantee badge persistent because a one-time disclosure (like Bryant's verbal statement) fades from memory; monthly reinforcement maintains confidence.

scan_order: Dollar amount: '$1,600' (anchor: 'that is my rent', under 1 second)
Action and date: 'released on March 2' or 'scheduled for March 2' (timing: 'I know exactly when', 1-3 seconds)
Guarantee badge: 'Guaranteed by Split Lease' (assurance: 'I am protected', 3-5 seconds)
Next payment preview: 'Next: $1,600 on April 2' (forward certainty: 'the next one is covered too', 5-7 seconds)
exclude: Notifications that require the host to take action to learn their payment status. If the host must log in, navigate, or tap to find out if they were paid, the proactive system has failed.
Financial jargon in notifications: 'disbursement,' 'remittance,' 'net of applicable fees.' Use 'released,' 'paid,' 'your $1,600.'
Notifications without the specific dollar amount. 'Your payment has been processed' is incomplete. The host needs to see '$1,600' every time.
Payment information only accessible on the Leases page. The assurance must be pushed to the host (email, SMS, push notification), not pulled by the host (checking a webpage).
Measuring payment system success by processing accuracy alone. Also measure host confidence: support contact frequency, Leases page check frequency, and post-lease retention correlation.

elements.title: Language-Accessible Information Design: Maximum 8-Word Sentences for Critical Decisions
elements.problem: Robbie is a non-native English speaker whose language difficulties are visible throughout the call: 'this me, where this have to be confirmed immediately. You feel the contract phone to, uh, to, to hold any property for you out loss' (04:06), 'The contract has been fueled' (06:14 -- likely meaning 'fulfilled'), and 'how many, something of the agreement you're talking about' (07:10). Each instance shows comprehension difficulty, not just expression difficulty. The Lean UX framework treats assumptions as hypotheses. The platform's unacknowledged assumption is that all hosts are fluent in English. Robbie invalidates this. Every interface using complex vocabulary, financial jargon, or multi-clause sentences will fail for hosts like Robbie. The language barrier is not a separate problem -- it is a multiplier that amplifies every other friction point. A payment explanation that confuses 20% of native speakers may confuse 60% of non-native speakers. Lean UX's GOOB principle (Getting Out of the Building) demands testing interfaces with the actual users they might fail for, not assuming they work for everyone.
elements.solution: Establish a language-accessible information design standard for all critical host-facing interfaces. The standard has four rules: (1) Maximum 8-word sentences for critical decisions (payment timing, agreement signing, pricing confirmation). Critical decisions are defined as any screen where the host might abandon if confused. (2) Visual communication alongside every financial concept: timelines for payment flow, side-by-side numbers for pricing, checkmarks for completed steps. Visual information crosses language barriers that text cannot. (3) Consistent terminology: never alternate between synonyms. If the call said 'rental agreement,' the platform says 'rental agreement' -- not 'lease contract' or 'tenancy document.' If the call said 'guests,' the platform says 'guests' -- not 'tenants' or 'residents.' (4) No idioms or colloquialisms: 'your payment is on its way' becomes 'your $1,600 was sent today.' Test the standard: recruit 5 non-native English speaking hosts and observe them completing each critical flow. Measure time, errors, and comprehension. The hypothesis: 'Language-accessible design will bring non-native speaker completion rates within 15 percentage points of native speaker rates.'

evidence.detail: Robbie: 'this me, where this have to be confirmed immediately. You feel the contract phone to, uh, to, to hold any property for you out loss.' The fragmented speech reveals he is processing complex financial concepts in a non-primary language. He understands the concept (payment must be confirmed) but cannot fully articulate or process it in English.

Gothelf (via Steve Blank): 'give potential customers a chance to provide feedback on your ideas sooner than you would have in the past. Much sooner. Test your ideas with a strong dose of reality while they're still young.' Testing with non-native speakers is GOOB applied to language accessibility.

Robbie: 'The contract has been fueled.' He likely means 'fulfilled' or 'filled.' If verbal English with live clarification available produces this level of processing difficulty, written English on a self-service platform without clarification will produce worse results.

Gothelf: 'Every project starts with assumptions, but usually we don't explicitly acknowledge this fact. Instead, we try to ignore assumptions, or worse, treat them as facts.' The assumption that all hosts are fluent English readers is exactly this kind of unacknowledged assumption. State it, test it, design for the result.

hierarchy_principle.primary: Visual elements: timelines, icons, checkmarks, and numbers. These cross language barriers and provide immediate comprehension regardless of English proficiency. The payment timeline (communicates-0902-001) is the archetype: four visual nodes convey the entire payment flow without requiring any sentence to be read.
hierarchy_principle.secondary: Short-sentence text: maximum 8 words for critical information. 'You get paid after the first night.' 'Sign two agreements.' 'Your rent is $1,600/month.' These are processable by non-native speakers because they contain one idea per sentence.
hierarchy_principle.tertiary: Extended explanations: available for hosts who want more detail, written in simple sentences but allowed to exceed the 8-word limit. These are behind expand/collapse elements and serve hosts who have stronger English or who want to verify their understanding.
hierarchy_principle.why: Robbie understood the financial concept he was trying to express (04:06) but could not process it in English. Visual elements bypass the language bottleneck entirely. Short sentences reduce the processing load for each text element. Extended explanations are available but never gating -- the host can complete critical flows using only visuals and short sentences.

disclosure_pattern.immediate: Visual elements and short-sentence labels. The critical action on any screen must be comprehensible through the visual alone, with the text serving as confirmation rather than primary communication.
disclosure_pattern.on_interaction: Extended text explanations for hosts who want more context. These appear on tap/expand and use simple sentence structure (subject-verb-object, no relative clauses).
disclosure_pattern.on_demand: Full documentation, agreement text, and detailed explanations. These are the deepest layer and are available for hosts with strong English or for hosts working with a translator.
disclosure_pattern.timing: Visual elements processable in under 3 seconds. Short-sentence labels processable in under 5 seconds. If a non-native speaker needs more than 5 seconds to understand what to do on a critical screen, the language design has failed.

cognitive_load_constraint.rationale: Eight words per critical sentence ensures each sentence contains one idea that can be parsed in a single reading pass. Visual alongside every financial concept because numbers and timelines are language-agnostic. Strict terminology consistency because synonym variation ('guests' vs 'tenants') forces the non-native speaker to determine whether the words mean the same thing, which is a comprehension task that native speakers perform automatically but non-native speakers must perform deliberately. No idioms because 'your payment is on its way' may not parse for a non-native speaker; 'your $1,600 was sent today' is concrete and unambiguous.

scan_order: Visual element: timeline, icon, or number (language-independent comprehension, under 2 seconds)
Short-sentence label: one idea, 8 words or fewer (language-dependent but minimal, 2-5 seconds)
Action button with short label: 'Sign,' 'Accept,' 'Next' (unambiguous, under 1 second)
Extended explanation on expand (optional, for hosts wanting more detail)
exclude: Multi-clause sentences in critical flows: 'After the first night of the booking, upon confirmation that the guest has checked in, your payment will be released.' Replace with: 'First night done. Payment released.'
Financial jargon: 'pre-authorized,' 'disbursement,' 'supplemental.' Replace with: 'collected,' 'paid,' 'extra agreement.'
Synonym variation within the same flow. If step 1 says 'guests,' step 2 must not say 'tenants.' If the call said 'rental agreement,' the platform must not say 'lease contract.'

Idioms or figurative language: 'your payment is on its way,' 'we've got you covered,' 'peace of mind.' Replace with concrete statements: 'your $1,600 was sent,' 'payment guaranteed,' 'you are protected.'
Dense paragraphs as the primary explanation for any concept. If it cannot be said in 8 words, it must be shown visually first and explained in text second.

The L1 element identified that verbal explanation failed as a hypothesis; L2 provides the information architecture for the alternative MVPs.
layer_1_alignment.ds-ui-0902-002_agent_to_platform_trust_b: Served directly by communicates-0902-002 (agent-attributed personalized landing page). The L1 element identified the trust gap; L2 defines the exact information hierarchy that bridges agent-mediated trust to self-service platform engagement.
layer_1_alignment.ds-ui-0902-003_import_existing_work: Served directly by communicates-0902-004 (import-and-verify listing path). The L1 element identified the waste in re-creation; L2 defines the information architecture that prioritizes verification over creation.
layer_1_alignment.ds-ui-0902-004_documents_as_comprehensio: Served directly by communicates-0902-003 (plain-language summary layer). The L1 element identified that documents must achieve comprehension, not just compliance; L2 defines the Q&A structure that precedes legal documents.
layer_1_alignment.ds-ui-0902-005_monthly_to_nightly_transl: Served directly by communicates-0902-005 (dual-format price display). The L1 element identified the mental model conflict; L2 defines the information hierarchy that always leads with the host's native format.

The L1 element identified the language barrier as a cross-cutting multiplier; L2 defines the information design constraints that reduce language-dependent comprehension failure.

methodology_notes: Seven information architecture elements extracted from the intersection of Robbie's call behavior patterns and Gothelf's Lean UX hypothesis-driven design framework. Each element specifies HOW information should be structured (hierarchy), WHEN it should be revealed (disclosure), HOW MUCH the host can process (cognitive load), and WHAT THE EYE HITS FIRST (scan order). The Lean UX lens transforms each element into a testable hypothesis with explicit success criteria and market feedback signals. Elements are ordered from the most critical comprehension failure (communicates-0902-001: payment timeline -- the single issue Robbie raised three times) through the trust bridge (002), document comprehension (003), listing efficiency (004), pricing translation (005), active lease confidence (006), and the cross-cutting language multiplier (007). Every element traces to observable behavior in the Robbie call and to specific Lean UX principles. No element specifies visual design, layout, or interaction patterns -- those belong to subsequent layers.
